column1: Canary Wharf is the secondary central business district of London on the Isle of Dogs. Along with the City of London
column2: it is one of the main financial centres of the United Kingdom and the world
column3: containing many of their tallest buildings
column4: including the third-tallest in the UK
column5: One Canada Square.Canary Wharf is 97 acres (39 hectares) and contains around 16
column9: 000 m2) of office and retail space.  It comprises many open areas
column11: Cabot Square and Westferry Circus. Together with Heron Quays and Wood Wharf
column12: it forms the Canary Wharf Estate.

column1: == History ==
Canary Wharf is located on the West India Docks on the Isle of Dogs.
West India Dock CompanyFrom 1802 to the late 1980s
column2: what would become the Canary Wharf Estate was a part of the Isle of Dogs (Millwall)
column3: Limehouse and Poplar and was one of the busiest docks in the world. After the 1960s
column4: the port industry began to decline
column5: leading to all the docks being closed by 1980. West India Docks was primarily developed by Robert Milligan (c. 1746–1809) who set up the West India Dock Company.

column1: Port of London AuthorityWest India Dock was by this time owned by the Port of London Authority in 1909. Canary Wharf itself takes its name from No. 32 berth of the West Wood Quay of the Import Dock. This was built in 1936 for Fruit Lines Ltd
column2: a subsidiary of Fred Olsen Lines for the Mediterranean and Canary Islands fruit trade. The Canary islands were so named after the large dogs found there by the Spanish (Canarias from Canine) and as it is located on the Isle of Dogs
column3: the quay and warehouse were given the name Canary Wharf.

column1: London Docklands Development CorporationAfter the docks closed in 1980
column2: the British Government adopted policies to stimulate redevelopment of the area
column3: including the creation of the London Docklands Development Corporation (LDDC) in 1981 and the granting of Urban Enterprise Zone status to the Isle of Dogs in 1982.The Canary Wharf of today began when Michael von Clemm
column4: former chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston (CSFB)
column5: came up with the idea to convert Canary Wharf into a back office. Further discussions with G Ware Travelstead led to proposals for a new business district and included the LDDC developing a cheap light metro scheme
column6: called the Docklands Light Railway to make use a large amount of redundant railway infrastructure and to improve access.

column1: The project was sold to the Canadian company Olympia & York and construction began in 1988
column2: master-planned by Skidmore
column3: Owings & Merrill with Yorke Rosenberg Mardall as their UK advisors
column4: and subsequently by Koetter Kim. The first buildings were completed in 1991
column6: which became the UK's tallest building at the time and a symbol of the regeneration of Docklands. By the time it opened
column7: the London commercial property market had collapsed
column8: and Olympia and York Canary Wharf Limited filed for bankruptcy in May 1992.

column1: Initially
column2: the City of London saw Canary Wharf as an existential threat. It modified its planning laws to expand the provision of new offices in the City of London
column3: for example
column4: creating offices above railway stations (Blackfriars) and roads (Alban Gate). The resulting oversupply of office space contributed to the failure of the Canary Wharf project.

column1: Canary Wharf GroupIn Oct. 1995
column2: an international consortium that included investors such as Alwaleed
column3: bought control for $1.2 billion.  Paul Reichmann was named chairman
column4: and Canary Wharf went public in 1999. The new company was called Canary Wharf Limited
column5: and later became Canary Wharf Group.

column2: some residents living on the Isle of Dogs launched a lawsuit against Canary Wharf Ltd for private nuisance because the tower interfered with TV signals. The residents lost the case.Recovery in the property market generally
column3: coupled with continuing demand for large floorplate Grade A office space
column4: slowly improved the level of interest. A critical event in the recovery was the much-delayed start of work on the Jubilee Line Extension
column5: which the government wanted ready for the Millennium celebrations.

column1: In March 2004
column2: Canary Wharf Group plc. was taken over by a consortium of investors
column3: backed by its largest shareholder Glick Family Investments and led by Morgan Stanley using a vehicle named Songbird Estates plc.

column1: == Leisure ==
MarinaWest India Quays and Poplar Dock are two marinas that are used as moorings for barges and private leisure river craft and is owned by the Canal & River Trust.
LibraryA local public library
column2: called Idea Store Canary Wharf
column3: is in Churchill Place shopping mall and run by Tower Hamlets Council which opened on Thursday 16 March 2006 as part of the Idea Store project and is the borough fourth Idea Store.

column1: CinemaCanary Wharf hosts two multiplexes (cinemas)
column2: one on West India Quay run by Cineworld. and another at Crossrail Place called Everyman Cinema.

column1: == Areas ==
Canada SquareCanada Square is one of the central squares at Canary Wharf.  It is a large open space with grass
column2: except during the winter when it is converted into an ice rink.  The square is named after Canada
column3: because the original developers of modern Canary Wharf
column5: wanted to reflect their heritage.  Underneath the square is Canada Place shopping mall.

column1: Westferry CircusWestferry Circus is on the west side of Canary Wharf. It is a garden at ground level
column2: and below is a roundabout allowing traffic to flow through.  The garden is enclosed by bespoke hand-crafted ornamental railings and entrance gates by artist Giuseppe Lund. The area has a long history
column3: dating back to 1812
column4: when the Poplar and Greenwich Roads Company operated a horse ferry between Greenwich and the Isle of Dogs. It operated on the West Ferry and East Ferry Roads
column5: which the names survived. Westferry Circus was chosen as the name for the roundabout and park by virtue of its proximity to Westferry Road.

column1: Cabot SquareCabot Square is one of the biggest squares at Canary Wharf
column2: with a large fountain at the centre. The inner perimeter has additional fountains covered by trees. The square has large circular glass ventilation holes to allow gases to escape from the underneath car park. The square is named after John Cabot and his son Sebastian
column3: who were Italian explorers who settled in England in 1484.

column1: Churchill PlaceChurchill Place is an area on the east side of Canary Wharf.  It is named after Winston Churchill.
Columbus CourtyardA small square on the west side of Canary Wharf named after Christopher Columbus. The first phase of Canary Wharf was completed in 1992
column2: 500 years after Columbus arrived in America.

column1: Chancellor PassageA passageway south of Cabot Square.  Named after Richard Chancellor who sailed with Sir John Willoughby from Greenwich on their voyage through the White Sea to Moscow.
Wren LandingSmall area north of Cabot Square. Leads to North Dock footbridge towards Port East. Named after British architect Christopher Wren.
== Local government elections ==
Every four years
column2: residents of Canary Wharf ward elect two councillors to represent them on Tower Hamlets Council.

column1: == Transport ==
Canary Wharf is served by London-wide
column2: regional
column3: national and international transport connections.

column1: === Rail ===
Canary Wharf is in London fare zone 2
column2: and several stations can be found throughout the estate.

column1: The Docklands Light Railway (DLR) calls at Canary Wharf
column2: Heron Quays and West India Quay stations. The line opened in 1987.DLR trains link Canary Wharf northbound to Bank in the City of London
column3: via Shadwell. Northbound trains also travel to Stratford via Poplar and Bow Church. Southbound trains terminate south of the River Thames in Lewisham

column1: London Underground Jubilee line services call at Canary Wharf station. Eastbound trains travel to Stratford via North Greenwich
column2: Canning Town and West Ham. Westbound trains link Canary Wharf to the  West End and key London interchanges including London Bridge
column3: Waterloo and Baker Street. Trains towards Central London eventually terminate in North West London.

column1: The Elizabeth Line (Crossrail) will call at Canary Wharf station. When the line opens
column2: the line will provide the area with a frequent
column3: direct connection to the City of London and the West End. Westbound trains will serve Central London and key interchanges at Liverpool Street and Paddington. Elizabeth line trains will also serve Heathrow Airport () and Reading
column4: Berkshire to the west. Eastbound services will terminate at Abbey Wood.Stations in Canary Wharf only offer direct connections to London and Berkshire destinations. Regional and national National Rail connections can be found elsewhere in London

column1: === Road ===
Major roads near Canary Wharf include:
A12 - begins in nearby Blackwall and carries traffic northeast towards Stratford
column2: the M11 (for Stansted Airport )
column3: and destinations in Essex and East Anglia.

column1: A13 (East India Dock Road) - westbound to Limehouse and the City of London (Aldgate); eastbound towards Barking
column2: the M25 and Southend ().

column1: A102 (Blackwall Tunnel) - begins in nearby Blackwall and carries traffic southbound to Greenwich
column2: the A2 and the A20 for destinations in Kent.

column1: A1020 (Lower Lea Crossing) - carries traffic eastbound to London City Airport ().
A1203 (Limehouse Link) - carries traffic eastbound to Shadwell and the City of London (Tower Hill).
A1205 (Burdett Road) - carries traffic northbound to Mile End and Hackney.
A1206 (Westferry Circus/Prestons Road) - loops around the western
column2: southern and eastern edges of the Isle of Dogs. Links to the A1261.

column1: A1261 (Aspen Way) - westbound to the A13 for Limehouse and the City; eastbound to the A1020 for City Airport () and the A13 towards Barking.
==== Air pollution ====
Transport for London (TfL) and the London Borough of Tower Hamlets monitor the air quality around Canary Wharf.

column2: an automatic monitoring station in Blackwall found that local air quality failed to meet UK National Air Quality Objectives
column3: recording an annual average Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) concentration of 56 μg/m3 (micrograms per cubic metre). The National Objective is set by the government at 40 μg/m3.

column1: Alternative stations nearer Canary Wharf recorded cleaner air. Monitors at the Limehouse Link/Westferry Road junction and on Prestons Road recorded a 2017 annual average NO2 concentration of 40 μg/m3
column2: which Tower Hamlets argue fails to meet the UK National Objective.

column1: === Buses ===
London Buses routes 135
column3: D3
column6: N277 and N550 call at bus stops near Canary Wharf. Bus 135 links Canary Wharf directly to Liverpool Street in the City of London

column1: === Riverboat ===
Several Riverboat services call at Canary Wharf Pier
column2: including:

column1: RB1 - eastbound to North Greenwich; westbound to Tower
column2: London Bridge City
column3: Bankside

column1: RB1X - eastbound to North Greenwich; westbound to Tower
column2: London Bridge City
column3: Bankside
column5: the London Eye and Westminster (limited service to Battersea Power Station).

column1: RB4 - crosses the Thames to Nelson Dock.
RB6 - limited eastbound service towards Putney.Tower
column2: London Bridge City and Blackfriars are in the City of London. Oyster Cards are valid for travel on TfL-coordinated riverboat services.

column1: === Airports ===
London City Airport is 3 miles from Canary Wharf. Over 4.8 million passengers passed through City Airport in 2018. The airport serves domestic and international destinations
column2: including New York.London City Airport is on the DLR. Passengers from Canary Wharf can change trains at Poplar for services to the Airport.

column1: === Cycling ===
The Canary Wharf Group
column2: London Borough of Tower Hamlets and Transport for London (TfL) provide cycling infrastructure in and around Canary Wharf. Several leisure and commuter routes pass through or near the estate
column3: including:

column1: National Cycle Route 1 (NCR 1) - a leisure cycle route from Dover
column2: Kent to Shetland
column3: Scotland. The route is indirect
column4: running through London on low-traffic paths. In North London
column5: the route runs from the Greenwich Foot Tunnel to Enfield Lock via Canary Wharf
column6: Mile End and Tottenham. The route runs to the west of Canary Wharf

column1: EuroVelo 2 ("The Capitals Route") - an international leisure cycle route from Moscow
column2: Russia to Galway
column3: Ireland. In North London
column4: EV2 follows the route of NCR 1.

column1: National Cycle Route 13 (NCR 13) - a leisure cycle route from the City to Fakenham
column2: Norfolk. The route is indirect
column3: running through East London on low-traffic paths. The route leaves London near Rainham.

column1: Cycle Superhighway 3 (CS3) - a commuter cycle route from Barking to West London. The route runs east-west through nearby Poplar on low-traffic or residential streets. The route is signposted and unbroken.East of Poplar
column2: the route to Barking predominantly runs on traffic-free cycle track.

column1: West of Limehouse
column2: the route runs on low-traffic or traffic-free paths to Shadwell. The route is signposted and unbroken. After Shadwell
column3: the route becomes a traffic-free cycle track which provides Canary Wharf with a direct link to Tower Hill
column7: Hyde Park Corner and Lancaster Gate.

column1: Cycleway from Hackney to the Isle of Dogs - proposed cycle link which would link Canary Wharf directly to Mile End on traffic-free cycle track.
Limehouse Cut towpath - shared-use path from nearby Limehouse to Stratford. The route is traffic-free.
Regent's Canal towpath - shared-use path from nearby Limehouse to Angel. The route is traffic-free and passes through Mile End
column2: Haggerston
column3: and Islington.

column1: == Culture ==
Opened in 2003
column2: the Museum of London Docklands is one of the  main attractions in the area.

column1: Canary Wharf has been reported since 2017 as part of the Pokémon Go augmented reality game to being the home for the most wanted Pokémon gyms in London including Canary Wharf DLR station and Montgomery Square.Canary Wharf Group published an official Pokémon map for PokéStop's and Pokémon Gyms
column2: the managing director for retail Camille Waxer said in 2016 that Pokémon Go has serious potential to attract new audiences to the area
column3: particularly food and drink outlets are seeing an increase in footfall.Canary Wharf hosts the "Winter Lights" art installations each January.Canary Wharf features in both the Doctor Who and Torchwood franchises as the fictional base of the Torchwood Institute
column4: an organization created by Queen Victoria to combat extraterrestrial threats. Canary Wharf features heavily as the staging post for the 2006 Cyberman invasion of Earth and is heavily damaged during a resulting battle between the Cybermen and the Daleks
column5: with the 10th Doctor and Rose Tyler caught in the middle.

column1: Thom Yorke of Radiohead
column2: during their concert Live at the Astoria in May 1994
column3: explained their song Fake Plastic Trees is about Canary Wharf.
